title: Txpool not receiving any new pending transactions

body: Can you try the latest release? We have a fix for txpool which may or may not solve this issue.
I will update if the issue continues on the latest release. It is rare so it could take some time.

I have also seen this issue. I first saw it happen on Apr 21 after upgrading to v1.9.13. I have also seen it happen frequently with v1.9.15. It is common enough (once every 2-5 days) that I have written a monitoring tool to detect the problem and restart geth when it happens. There is no indication in the log that something is wrong.

Here is an example incident using v1.9.15. Last pending tx seen at 2020-06-15 14:23:41, then sudden stop. At this time CPU load went ~75% idle. Nothing relevant in geth.log:
```

INFO [06-15|14:23:30.283] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1  txs=183 mgas=9.962  elapsed=2.534s    mgasps=3.930   number=10270819     hash="47f44d…676a68" dirty=774.22MiB
```

```
CPU (last column is idle%):

14:18:59        all     52.11      0.00      2.96      1.22      0.23     43.48

```
Upon sending the INT signal, geth begins shutdown but then hangs (as reported in #21273):
```
INFO [06-15|18:01:19.308] Got interrupt, shutting down...
INFO [06-15|18:01:19.317] WebSocket endpoint closed                url=ws://127.0.0.1:8546
INFO [06-15|18:01:19.317] HTTP endpoint closed                     url=http://127.0.0.1:8545/
INFO [06-15|18:01:19.318] IPC endpoint closed                      url=/mnt/data/geth/geth.ipc
```
Force stopped. Upon restart, full sync from 15h20m in the past.

In config.toml I have:
```
[Eth.TxPool]
Locals = []
NoLocals = false
Journal = "transactions.rlp"
Rejournal = 3600000000000
PriceLimit = 1
PriceBump = 10
AccountSlots = 16
GlobalSlots = 100000
AccountQueue = 64
GlobalQueue = 1024
Lifetime = 10800000000000
```

The issue disappeared after I did a few things. First updated to the latest version and set a lower txpool limit. Now I am using 75000 max `globalslots`.

Next I wrote a script that will run every minute. It drops nodes that are way behind in syncing. I did see a small improvement doing this, but I'm not sure if it was the main cause of the issue. I wouldn't recommend doing this unless you are using the node as a service provider. In my case, I need as close to 100% uptime as I can get.
